image.altText: Lia Finocchiaro and Gerard Maley

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory's new chief minister has announced an interim ministry while deciding on her full cabinet, as vote counting continues for two contested Darwin seats.

title.children: NT chief minister to hold 20 portfolios in two-person interim ministry before announcing new cabinet

image.altText: CFMEU MEMBERS RALLY BRISBANE

props.synopsis: Affiliation and donations to the ALP have been suspended, administrators forced in, and now Labor is using the bad stench around the CFMEU as a political weapon against the Greens.

title.children: With whiffs of Peter Dutton, Labor is now using the bad stench around the CFMEU as a weapon against the Greens

image.altText: Richard Marles National Press Club speech

props.synopsis: The defence minister requested a second office be opened for ministerial duties, just a three-minute walk from his electorate office.

title.children: Defence Minister Richard Marles opened $600k second office despite already having one three minutes away

image.altText: Aeroplanes fly the colours of french flag in the sky

props.synopsis: Paris comes alive once more, as the 17th Paralympic Games are set to open with the Opening Ceremony at the Place de la Concorde and along the Champs-Elysées. Follow live.

title.children: Paralympics launches in wave of colour at Paris Opening Ceremony

image.altText: A blurred photo of a dog.

props.synopsis: Despite Instagram's policies against explicit content, the ABC has uncovered dozens of accounts on the platform — each with hundreds of followers — sharing images and videos of dogs being sexually exploited as well as other types of animal cruelty.

title.children: Instagram awash with easily accessible, 'horrific' accounts depicting bestiality

image.altText: A billabong in front of a stretch of escarpment.

props.synopsis: Energy Resources of Australia claims the decision to refuse its Jabiluka mineral lease was unfair and that the Resources Minister Madeleine King met with the company for just 10 minutes before the decision.

title.children: Mining company ERA claims Jabiluka lease refusal 'secret' and 'unfair'

image.altText: A photo showing a man wearing glasses and wearing a black baseball cap, ookingdirectly at the camera

props.synopsis: The NT's new CLP government has promised to curb soaring crime with tougher laws and enforcement. But the manager of an Alice Springs shopping centre has found pulling back on security, instead of increasing it, has worked better.

title.children: The new NT government plans to toughen crime laws, but this shopping centre is suggesting an alternative

image.altText: Police tape across a road on a suburban street, with a police officer and police car in the background.

props.synopsis: Peter Gardiner, one of two brothers convicted of murdering 20-year-old Dillon Willis in 2021, has been given the mandatory sentence of life in prison.

title.children: Youngest of two brothers convicted of murdering man in Karama sentenced to life in prison

image.altText: Four remote voting stations next to each other.

props.synopsis: Nearly two-thirds of enrolled voters in some remote Northern Territory electorates didn't vote in the 2024 election. We asked Indigenous Territorians why voter turnout was so poor.

title.children: Hurt after failed Voice referendum linked to low remote voter turnout in NT election

image.altText: Men play on a footy field

props.synopsis: This bush footy competition brings hundreds of people to Alice Springs from remote communities each year, but a council ban means they will no longer be able to play finals in town.

title.children: Alice Springs council declares two-year ban on controversial bush footy finals, amid crime fears

image.altText: A man's legs, wearing a military uniform and boots, standing on a flag on the ground.

props.synopsis: A former Wagner Group mercenary sheds light on the organisation's inner workings, as well as its training and recruitment procedures as the private army announces it has pulled out of Ukraine.

title.children: Kirill wanted money for his family. To get it, he had to die for Putin

image.altText: Illuminated light bulb strands

props.synopsis: Australia's power market operator says the outlook has improved for the country's biggest grid, but the risks of delays to new projects loom large.

title.children: Immediate threat of summer blackouts eases but market operator warns risks remain

props.synopsis: Kidnapped from his Burkina Faso home at gunpoint in 2016, Ken Elliott survived seven years in the desert as a prisoner of Al Qaeda.

title.children: He endured scorpions, scurvy and deadly sandstorms. But Ken Elliott has never told his story of survival — until now

image.altText: A soldier holding a big gun runs across a sandy road in front of an armoured vehicle.

props.synopsis: At least nine Palestinians have been killed in Israeli raids and strikes on several towns in the north of the occupied West Bank, according to a Red Crescent spokesperson.

title.children: Nine Palestinians killed in Israeli raids and strikes on West Bank, humanitarian workers say

image.altText: A graduate holds on to his hat while talking on his mobile phone

props.synopsis: The federal government's proposal to cap international student enrolments has prompted dire warnings from parts of the sector about the economic fallout.

title.children: Universities warn international student cap could slash numbers further than intended

image.altText: A pair of pink ski on a grassy hill, snow-covered mountains in the background

props.synopsis: The recent hot spell may feel unfamiliar, but weather extremes are quickly becoming the norm, as climate change up-ends the winter seasons.

title.children: 'A hot mess': As Australia basks in sunshine, a heatwave of this magnitude in summer could be deadly, climate scientists say

image.altText: Wieambilla hideout

props.synopsis: A marathon five-week inquest into the devastating Wieambilla shootings, which claimed the lives of two young police officers and an innocent neighbour, has reached its final day.

title.children: Conspiracies, paranoia and tragedy: What we've learned from the Wieambilla shooting inquest

props.synopsis: Liberal frontbencher Simon Birmingham has pledged the Coalition would reverse the federal government's "stubborn" refusal to reopen Australia's embassy in Kyiv, following the lead of numerous nations who have returned their diplomats to war-torn Ukraine.

title.children: Coalition pledges to reopen Australia's empty embassy in Ukraine's capital, during visit to Kyiv

image.altText: A man holding a pipe connected to sewage truck.

props.synopsis: More than 700 homes in eight new housing estates are having their sewage transported by road to Adelaide's main wastewater treatment plant, reflecting a national underinvestment in infrastructure.

title.children: 'It's unbearable': Sewage trucked daily from housing estates in Adelaide's north will continue for years

image.altText: Adam Bandt press club

props.synopsis: Content-wise, the Greens leader unabashedly promoted his movement's progressive ambitions to tax big corporations. But in style, his performance was pure Donald.

title.children: Adam Bandt's press club address was pure Trump, at least as far as style is concerned

image.altText: A woman smiling

props.synopsis: Polls put Kamala Harris slightly ahead of Donald Trump in the US election race. But there are two potential stumbling blocks that could up-end the contest once again.

title.children: Kamala Harris is ahead of Donald Trump, but two big wildcards could up-end the race

image.altText: Bentinck Island fish traps from the air

props.synopsis: Traditional owners say World Heritage listing would help preserve Australia's largest archaeological site, an elaborate network of stone walls designed to trap fish at low tide in the Gulf of Carpentaria.

title.children: Calls to protect northern Australia's ancient stone wall fish traps from tourists, climate change

image.altText: cash lays on a kitchen table beside a cup of tea and a list of bills owing

props.synopsis: The annual rate of inflation declined in July, as commonwealth and state rebates drove energy prices lower, the Bureau of Statistics said.

title.children: Inflation falls to 3.5pc in July as energy rebates help to push electricity prices lower

image.altText: big build photo generic

props.synopsis: Federal Infrastructure Minister Catherine King has been rolled in her efforts to decrease the Commonwealth's share of major transport funding, with Tasmania and WA joining a state and territory pile-on.

title.children: State and territory pressure mounts on Catherine King as transport funding deal risks derailment

image.altText: A composite image of Brittany Higgins and Linda Reynolds.

props.synopsis: Linda Reynolds's lawyer casts doubt on medical reports that claim Brittany Higgins is unfit to give evidence in the high-stakes defamation trial underway in Perth.

title.children: Medical reports failed to excuse Brittany Higgins from giving evidence, defamation trial told

image.altText: A clear IV drip with cords attached against a white wall.

props.synopsis: Federal Health Minister Mark Butler said the additional bags would ensure there was "more than enough to meet Australian demand over that period".

title.children: Federal government secures 22 million IV fluid bags amid global shortage

image.altText: CCTV shows a man in a cap and button up running away.

props.synopsis: The baby boy was with his family in a park at Stones Corner when an unknown man allegedly approached them and poured boiling coffee over the infant.

title.children: Baby burned after stranger allegedly threw hot coffee in 'deliberate' attack at a Brisbane park

image.altText: Firefighter Edmonsen Park fire

props.synopsis: Authorities have downgraded a fire emergency in Sydney's south-west that had earlier threatened homes and has left several people injured.

title.children: Several people injured and homes threatened by grass fire in Sydney's south-west

image.altText: A man in a hospital bed with tubes going into his nose and mouth.

props.synopsis: Hepatitis C attacked Dennis Maby's liver over two decades and nearly claimed his life. Now clear of the disease he's urging other people to get tested.

title.children: There's now a cure for Hepatitis C. Finding the people who need it is the challenge

image.altText: A dam.

props.synopsis: The Medlow Dam in the Blue Mountains has been disconnected by WaterNSW as a "precautionary measure" as investigations continue into the presence of PFAS, known as "forever chemicals", in the water.

title.children: Blue Mountains dam shut after detection of 'forever chemicals'

image.altText: Rear view of woman in hospital gown sitting on bed.

props.synopsis: Australia's largest health and medical research funding body has recommended sex, gender, variations of sex characteristics and sexual orientation be routinely considered in health and medical research.

title.children: Medical research has a sex and gender problem. New standards hope to change that

image.altText: Maggie Ayres typing on a computer while seated.

props.synopsis: Romance scams are on the rise in WA, with authorities warning people to be vigilant of scammers using artificial intelligence to disguise themselves in video calls.

title.children: Maggie thought she found love online, before a video call glitch showed a man in a cupboard covered with a blanket

image.altText: Cows graze in long grass on a roadside.

props.synopsis: The retailer updated its sustainability target, shifting from an existing net-zero deforestation goal, to become "deforestation-free" by the December 2025.

title.children: Woolworths supermaket says it will sell deforestation-free beef from end of 2025

image.altText: Mano Yogalingham smiles, dressed in a white shirt as he sits indoors.

props.synopsis: Friends of 23-year-old Mano Yogalingam told the ABC the young father arrived in Australia from Sri Lanka in 2013 and had been on a bridging visa for roughly 11 years.

title.children: Grief and shock in Melbourne after Tamil asylum seeker dies by self-immolation
